  • Look-then-leap

Optimal solution for stopping: Define how much time you are willing to spend. Spend some time gathering information first in the "look" phase. Then, in the "Leap" phase, be prepared to instantly commit to an option that looks better than all options in the first phase.

  • Full information and the Threshold rule

In the secretary problem, we don't have full information. All we have to work with is how they compare relatively to each other.

If for example, all we cared about was typing speed, then we would have full information.

When there are many options left in the pool, pass up on a good candidate in search of a better one. As the options dwindle, then lower standards. The math comes out to 58% success rate when using the threshold rule with full information, rather than 37% percent of the time, with no information using the look than leap rule.

Any measurement that provides a quantitative data on how the applicant lies relatively to the population will push the optimal strategy from look-then-leap to threshold rule.

  • People tend to stop early. The time cost of searching is not captured by the optimal stopping problem
